instruction: What metric was chosen to evaluate the accuracy of tissue classification using hyperspectral imaging, and how far can this metric go?
Output:
The metric chosen to evaluate the accuracy of tissue classification using hyperspectral imaging in this study is the accuracy score. The accuracy score measures the proportion of correctly classified tissue samples out of the total number of samples. 

The accuracy score achieved in this study was 0.88 (STD = 0.13) on the test dataset when distinguishing between fat, healthy colorectal wall, and tumor tissue. When the accuracy was determined per patient, a mean accuracy of 0.93 (STD = 0.12) was obtained on the test dataset.

The accuracy metric provides information on the overall performance of the tissue classification using hyperspectral imaging. It indicates how well the system is able to correctly identify different tissue types. In this study, the accuracy scores suggest that hyperspectral imaging has the potential to accurately classify tissue types in colorectal cancer surgery.

However, it is important to note that the accuracy metric alone does not provide information on the specific types of errors made by the system. Further research and evaluation are needed to assess the sensitivity, specificity, and other performance measures of the hyperspectral imaging technique in a clinical setting.
